results.title: The Liners
results.creator_credit: Rob McAuley, ABC-TV (Australia), Channel Four and Peter Butt
results.brief_description: Ocean liners were far more than simply giant ships that carried passengers across the seas. They were bold statements of national power and technological might. Like rocket ships in the space race of the 1970s, liners were symbols of ultimate power in the early struggle between the super-powers for dominance of the world. For the first time, the global story of these great ships - an epic story inextricably linked with epic world events is told. From the earliest days of the paddle-wheeled superliner; through their use in times of war as well as peace; into the present, and beyond, for a preview of giant ocean going cities already in the advance planning stages.

results.title: The Linear accelerator
results.brief_description: Using animation, this film introduces the theory of nuclear transmutations and the production of hard X-rays with laboratory-accelerated particles.

results.title: The Line
results.creator_credit: Gil Brealey, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Christopher McGill
results.brief_description: Made to commemorate the first crossing of Australia by the standard gauge railway line between Sydney and Perth. It does not attempt to trace this trip, rather capture the spirit of the crossing, to the accompaniment of a folk song and natural sounds.

results.title: The Lindsay Kemp Circus
results.creator_credit: Contemporary Films, Douglas Eadie and Oscar Marzaroli
results.brief_description: Presents Lindsay Kemp, the most accomplished mime artist to emerge from Britain, his extraordinary co-star Orlando and their troupe. The film reflects the “lush decadence” of their work - Kemp performing the ultimate tatty striptease and Orlando singing “I Must Have A Man”.

results.title: The Lin family shop = Linjia puzi [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Peking Film Studio, Shih Ping, Li Kan and Shui Hua
results.brief_description: At the centre of the story is a small-time merchant’s struggle for financial survival in a provincial town in the early 1930s. The novel by Yuan Chu and Mao Tun from which it was adapted came out of the May 4th Movement and has been described as ‘a lament for the patriotic bourgeoisie suffering from economic hardship of foreign competition’. Literature from this politically radical and western influenced movement became the subject of popularisation on the screen in the 1950s (see also Early Spring). Most pre-1949 filmmakers had been part of this cultural strain (see Street Angel). ‘The Lin Family Shop’ is regarded as the best of such fifties adaptations. The period is carefully evoked but the filmmakers were aware of the need to prevent audience identification with the shopkeeper who remains an understandable (if hardly sympathetic) figure. A narrator at the end provides the ‘right perspective’. Cast includes Wei Wei, Hsieh Tien, Han Tao. In Mandarin with English subtitles.

results.title: The Limits to growth
results.creator_credit: Osborn Segerberg and United Nations Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man builds - man destroys”.
Massachusetts Institute of Technology published a book, “The Limits to Growth”. Questions raised by that book included: Is it time to stop growing - in population, in capital investments, in material things - or is that the road to continued poverty for the poorer nations of the world? This film examines both sides of the question.
